title: Relative Clauses - Which, That or Nothing 3
instructions: Complete the sentences with the appropriate relative pronoun, B1whichB2, B1thatB2 or wherever it is possible B1nothingB2.

explain: Corr: which or that. Here the relative pronoun is the subject of the relative clause, so we cannot leave out the relative pronoun.

sentence: I couldn't recognise the city over
explain: Corr: which. There's a preposition so we cannot leave out the relative pronoun and only 'which' is correct because after prepositions we cannot use 'that'.

sentence: This is the part because of
the car stopped. At the moment, I don't have anything
explain: Corr: which. There's a preposition so we need to use a relative pronoun and it has to be 'which' because 'that' is not used after prepositions.
Corr: that or which. Here the relative pronoun is the subject of the relative clause, so we cannot leave it out. As there's 'anything' in the clause, 'that' is a better solution than 'which'.

sentence: I was drunk last night so I don't remember the things
explain: Corr: which, that or nothing. We can leave out the relative pronoun because it's not the subject of the relative clause. Its subject is 'I'.

sentence: Our city sports two huge stadiums
explain: Corr: which or that. We cannot leave out the relative pronoun because it's the subject of the relative clause.

sentence: Only one sandwich? Is that all
explain: Corr: that or which. The relative pronoun is the subject of the relative clause, so we cannot leave it out. Here, as there's 'all' in the sentence, 'that' is a better solution that 'which'. The word 'which' would sound unnatural after 'all'.
